title: enONE_tutorial
text: hub metabolite, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), can used initiating nucleotide RNA transcription result NAD-capped RNAs (NAD-RNAs). Epitranscriptome-wide profiling NAD-RNAs involves chemo-enzymatic labeling affinity-based enrichment; yet currently available computational analysis adequately remove variations inherently linked capture procedures. , propose spike--based normalization data-driven evaluation framework, enONE, omic-level analysis NAD-capped RNAs. enONE package implemented R publicly available https://github.com/thereallda/enONE.

title: enONE_tutorial
text: tutorial, demonstrate enONE workflow using NAD-RNA-seq data human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Notably, included three types spike-RNAs: Total RNAs Drosophila melanogaster, invertebrate model organism well-annotated genome sequence, estimating unwanted variation; Synthetic RNAs, consisting 5% NAD- relative m7G-capped forms, used determine capture sensitivity; Synthetic RNAs, 100% m7G-capped forms, used determine capture specificity (Figure1 ).  Figure 1: Schematic workflow total RNAs PBMCs three sets spike-ins. start reading data, including count matrix metadata. recommended provide assay group samples assay column metadata. Next, use count matrix create Enone object. Enone object serves container contains data (raw normalized counts data) analysis (e.g., normalization performance evaluation score enrichment results) NAD-RNA-seq dataset. constructing Enone object, can provide following arguments: Prefix spike-genes (spike..prefix = "^FB"); id synthetic spike-(synthetic.id = c("Syn1", "Syn2")), row names counts_mat; id input (input.id = "Input") enrichment (enrich.id = "Enrich"), assay column. , “Syn1” represent spike-5% NAD-RNA “Syn2” spike-100% m7G-RNA. Notably, batch.group , synthetic.id optional.
code: library(enONE) library(tidyverse) library(patchwork)  # read in metadata and counts matrix counts_mat <- read.csv("data/Counts.csv", row.names = 1) meta <- read.csv("data/metadata.csv", comment.char = "#") head(meta) #>   id sample.id condition batch assay #> 1 D1        Y2   Y.Input     D Input #> 2 D2       Y10   Y.Input     D Input #> 3 D3       Y14   Y.Input     D Input #> 4 D4       Y16   Y.Input     D Input #> 5 D5       M13   M.Input     D Input #> 6 D6       M14   M.Input     D Input # prefix of Drosophila spike-in genes spikeInPrefix <- "^FB"  # create Enone Enone <- createEnone(data = counts_mat,                      bio.group = meta$condition,                      enrich.group = meta$assay,                      batch.group = meta$batch,                      spike.in.prefix = spikeInPrefix,                      synthetic.id = c("Syn1", "Syn2"),                       input.id = "Input",                      enrich.id = "Enrich"                      ) Enone #> class: Enone  #> dim: 76290 62  #> metadata(0): #> assays(1): '' #> rownames(76290): ENSG00000223972 ENSG00000227232 ... Syn1 Syn2 #> rowData names(3): GeneID SpikeIn Synthetic #> colnames(62): D1 D2 ... F22 F24 #> colData names(5): id condition enrich replicate batch

title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE workflow consists four steps: Quality control; Gene set selection; Normalization procedures; Normalization performance assessment.

title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE initiate quality control step filter lowly-expressed genes. step performed FilterLowExprGene keeping genes least min.count least n samples. n determined smallest group sample size specifying group . Additionally, outliers can assessed removed (return=TRUE) OutlierTest. Since sample flagged outlier, use samples following analysis.
code: Enone <- FilterLowExprGene(Enone, group = Enone$condition, min.count = 20) Enone #> class: Enone  #> dim: 27661 62  #> metadata(0): #> assays(1): '' #> rownames(27661): ENSG00000227232 ENSG00000268903 ... Syn1 Syn2 #> rowData names(3): GeneID SpikeIn Synthetic #> colnames(62): D1 D2 ... F22 F24 #> colData names(5): id condition enrich replicate batch ## ronser"s test for outlier assessment OutlierTest(Enone, return=FALSE) #> Rosner's outlier test #>   i        Mean.i     SD.i    Value Obs.Num    R.i+1 lambda.i+1 Outlier #> 1 0  1.158348e-16 51.77231 80.37523      15 1.552475   3.212165   FALSE #> 2 1 -1.317627e+00 51.14304 78.20437      19 1.554894   3.205977   FALSE #> 3 2 -2.642993e+00 50.50717 70.38990      41 1.445991   3.199662   FALSE

title: enONE_tutorial
text: main enONE function can used perform gene selection, normalization, evaluation. function return selected gene set rowData, normalized count matrix counts slot (return.norm=TRUE), normalization factors (enone_factor slot), evaluation metrics scores enone_metrics enone_scores slots, respectively. Detailed steps described bellow.
code: Enone <- enONE(Enone,                 scaling.method = c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"),                ruv.norm = TRUE, ruv.k = 3,                eval.pam.k = 2:6, eval.pc.n = 3,                 return.norm = TRUE                ) #> Gene set selection for normalization and assessment... #> - The number of negative control genes for normalization: 1000  #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  #> - The number of positive evaluation genes: 500  #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  #> - The number of negative evaluation genes: 500  #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  #> Apply normalization... #> - Scaling...  #> - Regression-based normalization...  #> Perform assessment...

title: enONE_tutorial
text: gene set selection, enONE defined three sets control genes, including: Negative Control (NegControl): default, enONE define 1,000 least significantly enriched genes Drosophila spike-ins (RNA spike-exogenous organism), ranked FDR, negative controls adjustment unwanted variations. Negative Evaluation (NegEvaluation): default, enONE define 500 least significantly varied genes samples interest, ranked FDR, negative evaluation genes evaluation unwanted variations. Positive Evaluation (PosEvaluation): default, enONE define 500 significantly enriched genes samples interest, ranked FDR, positive evaluation genes evaluation wanted variations. Gene set selection can either automatically defined enONE function auto=TRUE parameter (default), provided neg.control, pos.eval, neg.eval parameters, respectively. Selected gene sets can assessed getGeneSet name gene set (.e., "NegControl", "NegEvaluation", "PosEvaluation").
code: getGeneSet(Enone, "NegControl")[1:5] #> [1] "FBgn0031247" "FBgn0031255" "FBgn0004583" "FBgn0031324" "FBgn0026397"

title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE implements global scaling regression-based methods generation normalization procedures. global scaling normalization procedures, five different scaling procedures implemented, including Total Count (TC); Upper-Quartile (UQ); Trimmed Mean M Values (TMM); DESeq; PossionSeq. default, enONE uses scaling methods, user can perform selected scaling procedures scaling.method parameter. regression-based procedures, enONE use three variants RUV estimate factors unwanted variation, including RUVg; RUVs; RUVse. instance, can perform RUV selected first two unwanted factors ruv.norm=TRUE, ruv.k=2. RUVse modification RUVs. estimated factors unwanted variation based negative control genes replicate samples assay group (.e., enrichment input), enrichment effect assumed constant. applied normalization methods can assessed listNormalization Normalized counts can assessed Counts
code: listNormalization(Enone) #>  [1] "TC"                  "UQ"                  "TMM"                 #>  [4] "DESeq"               "PossionSeq"          "Raw"                 #>  [7] "Raw_RUVg_k1"         "Raw_RUVg_k2"         "Raw_RUVg_k3"         #> [10] "Raw_RUVs_k1"         "Raw_RUVs_k2"         "Raw_RUVs_k3"         #> [13] "Raw_RUVse_k1"        "Raw_RUVse_k2"        "Raw_RUVse_k3"        #> [16] "TC_RUVg_k1"          "TC_RUVg_k2"          "TC_RUVg_k3"          #> [19] "TC_RUVs_k1"          "TC_RUVs_k2"          "TC_RUVs_k3"          #> [22] "TC_RUVse_k1"         "TC_RUVse_k2"         "TC_RUVse_k3"         #> [25] "UQ_RUVg_k1"          "UQ_RUVg_k2"          "UQ_RUVg_k3"          #> [28] "UQ_RUVs_k1"          "UQ_RUVs_k2"          "UQ_RUVs_k3"          #> [31] "UQ_RUVse_k1"         "UQ_RUVse_k2"         "UQ_RUVse_k3"         #> [34] "TMM_RUVg_k1"         "TMM_RUVg_k2"         "TMM_RUVg_k3"         #> [37] "TMM_RUVs_k1"         "TMM_RUVs_k2"         "TMM_RUVs_k3"         #> [40] "TMM_RUVse_k1"        "TMM_RUVse_k2"        "TMM_RUVse_k3"        #> [43] "DESeq_RUVg_k1"       "DESeq_RUVg_k2"       "DESeq_RUVg_k3"       #> [46] "DESeq_RUVs_k1"       "DESeq_RUVs_k2"       "DESeq_RUVs_k3"       #> [49] "DESeq_RUVse_k1"      "DESeq_RUVse_k2"      "DESeq_RUVse_k3"      #> [52] "PossionSeq_RUVg_k1"  "PossionSeq_RUVg_k2"  "PossionSeq_RUVg_k3"  #> [55] "PossionSeq_RUVs_k1"  "PossionSeq_RUVs_k2"  "PossionSeq_RUVs_k3"  #> [58] "PossionSeq_RUVse_k1" "PossionSeq_RUVse_k2" "PossionSeq_RUVse_k3" head(Counts(Enone, slot="sample", method="DESeq_RUVg_k2"))[,1:5] #>                        D1        D2        D3        D4        D5 #> ENSG00000227232  8.513191 11.644149 12.430311  7.452931 11.103087 #> ENSG00000268903  3.305178  8.099601  5.277247 26.323356  7.087624 #> ENSG00000269981  2.270170  4.876260  2.402558 18.116461  6.067605 #> ENSG00000279457 11.894618  9.997839  8.759756 11.203303 16.374378 #> ENSG00000225630 13.766308 16.291397 15.364064 10.139363 17.832904 #> ENSG00000237973 28.039373 37.273703 39.843934 34.075036 33.948773

title: enONE_tutorial
text: evaluate performance normalization, enONE leverages eight normalization performance metrics related different aspects distribution gene expression measures. eight metrics listed : BIO_SIM: Similarity biological groups. average silhouette width clusters defined bio.group, computed Euclidean distance metric first 3 expression PCs (default). Large values BIO_SIM desirable. EN_SIM: Similarity enrichment groups. average silhouette width clusters defined en.group, computed Euclidean distance metric first 3 expression PCs (default). Large values EN_SIM desirable. BAT_SIM: Similarity batch groups. average silhouette width clusters defined batch.group, computed Euclidean distance metric first 3 expression PCs (default). Low values BAT_SIM desirable. PAM_SIM: Similarity PAM clustering groups. maximum average silhouette width clusters defined PAM clustering (cluster eval.pam.k), computed Euclidean distance metric first 3 expression PCs (default). Large values BAT_SIM desirable. WV_COR: Preservation biological variation. R2 measure regression first 3 expression PCs first eval.pc.n PCs positive evaluation genes (PosEvaluation) sub-matrix raw count. Large values WV_COR desirable. UV_COR: Removal unwanted variation. R2 measure regression first 3 expression PCs first eval.pc.n PCs negative evaluation genes (NegEvaluation) sub-matrix raw count. Low values UV_COR desirable. RLE_MED: mean squared-median Relative Log Expression (RLE). Low values RLE_MED desirable. RLE_IQR: variance inter-quartile range (IQR) RLE. Low values RLE_IQR desirable. Evaluation metrics can assessed getMetrics Evaluation score average rank performance metrics, can assessed getScore

what: Select the suitable normalization for subsequent analysis
title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE provides biplot exploit full space normalization methods, can turn interactive mode interactive=TRUE.  plot, point corresponds normalization procedure colored performance score (mean eight scone performance metric ranks). blue arrows correspond PCA loadings performance metrics. direction length blue arrow can interpreted measure much metric contributed first two PCs , use top-ranked procedure DESeq_RUVg_k2 downstream analysis. noted, normalized counts returned enONE run step (.e., return.norm=FALSE), can manually perform normalization method, e.g.,
code: # get performance score enScore <- getScore(Enone) # perform PCA based on evaluation score, excluding BAT_SIM column (3) if no batch information provided, and SCORE column (9). # pca.eval <- prcomp(enScore[,-c(3, 9)], scale = TRUE) pca.eval <- prcomp(enScore[,-c(9)], scale = TRUE) # pca biplot PCA_Biplot(pca.eval, score = enScore$SCORE, interactive = FALSE) # select normalization norm.method <- rownames(enScore[1,])  # get normalized counts norm.data <- Counts(Enone, slot = "sample", method = norm.method)  # get normalization factors norm.factors <- getFactor(Enone, slot = "sample", method = norm.method)  norm.method #> [1] "DESeq_RUVg_k2" # perform normalization Enone <- UseNormalization(Enone, slot = "sample", method = norm.method) # get normalized counts norm.data <- Counts(Enone, slot = "sample", method = norm.method)

title: enONE_tutorial
text: perform PCA based count matrix sample interest normalization, demonstrating effect normalization.
code: # create sample name, e.g., Y3.Input samples_name <- paste(Enone$condition, Enone$replicate, sep=".")  # PCA for raw count p1 <- PCAplot(Counts(Enone, slot="sample", "Raw"),              color = Enone$batch,             shape = Enone$enrich,             label = samples_name,              vst.norm = TRUE) +    ggtitle("Before normalization")  # PCA for normalized count p2 <- PCAplot(log1p(norm.data),              color = Enone$batch,             shape = Enone$enrich,             label = samples_name,              vst.norm = FALSE) +    ggtitle("After normalization")  # combine two plots p1 + p2

title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE package can help find enrichment genes biological groups via differential expression. can identify genes significantly increased enrichment samples compared input samples. FindEnrichment automates processes groups provided bio.group. default, enriched genes (NAD-RNA ) defined fold change normalized transcript counts ≥ 2 (logfc.cutoff = 1), FDR < 0.05 (p.cutoff = 0.05) enrichment samples compared input samples. Use getEnrichment retrieve list enrichment result tables. enrichment table data.frame list genes rows, associated information columns (GeneID, logFC, p-values, etc.). following columns present table: GeneID: ID genes. logFC: log2 fold-change enrichment input samples. Positive values indicate gene highly enriched enrichment group. logCPM: log2 CPM (counts per million) average expression samples. LR: Likelihood ratio likelihood ratio test. PValue: p-value likelihood ratio test. FDR: False discovery rate p-value, default “BH” method applied. convert list enrichment result tables data frame long format, enONE package provide reduceRes function task. Finally, can use BetweenStatPlot compare global extent NAD-RNA modification level groups.
code: # find all enriched genes Enone <- FindEnrichment(Enone, slot="sample", method = norm.method,                          logfc.cutoff = 1, p.cutoff = 0.05) #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  # get filtered enrichment results res.sig.ls <- getEnrichment(Enone, slot="sample", filter=TRUE)  # count number of enrichment in each group unlist(lapply(res.sig.ls, nrow)) #> Y.Enrich_Y.Input M.Enrich_M.Input O.Enrich_O.Input  #>              579              672              683 head(res.sig.ls[[1]]) #>            GeneID    logFC   logCPM       LR        PValue           FDR #> 1 ENSG00000013275 2.272071 7.518248 732.1665 3.027700e-161 4.187309e-157 #> 2 ENSG00000113387 2.643445 9.732201 632.0043 1.831945e-139 1.266790e-135 #> 3 ENSG00000104853 2.244864 7.839309 588.0558 6.634253e-130 3.058391e-126 #> 4 ENSG00000105185 2.094523 6.147943 558.6765 1.631268e-123 5.640108e-120 #> 5 ENSG00000143110 3.084632 9.116028 550.2734 1.097768e-121 3.036425e-118 #> 6 ENSG00000173915 2.325200 7.005518 484.0091 2.866741e-107 6.607839e-104 # simplify group id names(res.sig.ls) <- c("Young", "Mid", "Old")  # logfc.col specify the name of logFC column nad_df1 <- reduceRes(res.sig.ls, logfc.col = "logFC")  # convert the Group column as factor nad_df1$Group <- factor(nad_df1$Group, levels = unique(nad_df1$Group))  # draw plot bxp1 <- BetweenStatPlot(nad_df1, x="Group", y="logFC", color="Group",                          step.increase = 0.6, add.p = "p",                          comparisons = list(c("Young", "Mid"),                                             c("Young", "Old"))) bxp1

title: enONE_tutorial
text: Since synthetic RNAs, one 5% NAD-caps another 100% m7G-caps, included, can use spike-ins determine capture sensitivity specificity. synEnrichment calculate enrichment levels synthetic spike-ins given normalization method. DotPlot can used visualize enrichment levels synthetic spike-.  Syn1, contained 5% NAD-RNA, significantly enriched, whereas enrichment found Syn2 made 100% m7G-RNA.
code: # compute synthetic spike-in enrichment syn_level <- synEnrichment(Enone, method=norm.method, log=TRUE)  # transform to long format syn_df <- as.data.frame(syn_level) %>%    rownames_to_column("syn_id") %>%    pivot_longer(cols = -syn_id,                names_to = "id",                values_to = "logFC") %>%    left_join(meta[,c("id","condition")], by="id")  # remove suffix of condition for simplification syn_df$condition <- gsub("\\..*", "", syn_df$condition)  # rename facet label samples_label <- setNames(c("5% NAD-RNA", "100% m7G-RNA"),                            nm=c("Syn1", "Syn2"))  # draw dotplot DotPlot(syn_df, x="syn_id", y="logFC", fill="syn_id") +   theme(legend.position = "none") +   scale_x_discrete(labels=samples_label) #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`. # save Enone data save(Enone, file="data/Enone.RData")

code: @Manual{,   title = {enONE: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis by spike-in based Omic-level Normalization and Evaluation},   author = {Dean Li},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://thereallda.github.io/enONE/}, }

what: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis by spike-in based Omic-level Normalization and Evaluation
title: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis by spike-in based Omic-level Normalization and Evaluation
text: enONE R package performing spike-based normalization NAD-capped RNA sequencing data, well comparing ranking performance different normalization strategies. enONE also provides toolkit handle NAD-RNA sequencing data.

title: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis by spike-in based Omic-level Normalization and Evaluation
text: can install development version enONE GitHub : Tutorial can found https://thereallda.github.io/enONE/
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("thereallda/enONE")

what: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
text: Applies normalization sequencing data

title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
code: ApplyNormalization(   data,   scaling.method = c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"),   ruv.norm = TRUE,   ruv.k = 1,   ruv.drop = 0,   control.idx = NULL,   sc.idx = NULL,   enrich.idx = NULL,   spike.in.prefix = NULL )

title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
text: data un-normalized count data matrix shape n x p, n number samples p number features. scaling.method Vector normalization methods applied data. Available methods : c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"). Select one multiple methods. default normalization methods applied. ruv.norm Whether perform RUV normalization. ruv.k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. ruv.drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input. control.idx Vector negative control genes RUV normalization. sc.idx numeric matrix specifying replicate samples compute count differences used estimate factors unwanted variation. enrich.idx Matrix two rows indicating column index enrichment input samples raw/normalized count data matrix. first row column index input second row column index enrichment samples. spike..prefix character specify prefix spike-id.

title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
text: List objects containing normalized data associated normalization factors.

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization
text: Assessments normalization performance

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization
text: data.ls List containing normalized counts adjust factors adjusting unwanted variation. Output ApplyNormalization. bio.group Vector index indicating column index samples biological groups raw/normalized count data matrix. enrich.group Vector index indicating column index enrichment input samples raw/normalized count data matrix. batch.group Vector index indicating column index batch groups raw/normalized count data matrix. eval.pam.k Integer vector integers indicates number clusters PAM clustering performance evaluation, default: 2:6. eval.pc.n Integer indicates evaluation metrics calculated first nth PCs, default: 3. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix, default: TRUE. pos.eval.set Vector genes id. neg.eval.set Vector genes id.

title: Esimate sequencing depth — PS.Est.Depth
text: n data matrix. rows counts gene, columns counts experiment. iter Number iterations used. Default value: 5. default value usually good choice. ct.sum total number reads gene across experiments <= ct.sum, gene considered estimating sequencing depth. Default value: 5. ct.mean mean number reads gene across experiments <= ct.mean, gene considered estimating sequencing depth. Default value: 0.5.

title: Esimate sequencing depth — PS.Est.Depth
text: estimated sequencing depth. vector. product 1.

Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
text: Enone object extends SummarizedExperiment class. createEnone easy constructor Enone object

title: Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
code: createEnone(   data,   bio.group,   enrich.group,   batch.group = NULL,   spike.in.prefix = NULL,   input.id = "Input",   enrich.id = "Enrich",   synthetic.id = NULL )

title: Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
text: data un-normalized count data matrix shape n x p, n number samples p number features. bio.group Vector samples group, e.g., c("Young.Input","Young.Enrich","Old.Input","Old.Enrich"). enrich.group Vector enrichment group, e.g., c("Input","Enrich","Input","Enrich"). batch.group Vector samples batch, e.g., c("","","B","B"), default: NULL. spike..prefix character specify prefix spike-id, e.g., "^FB" stands fly spike-id, default: NULL. input.id Input library id, must consistent enrich.group, e.g., "Input". enrich.id Enrich library id, must consistent enrich.group, e.g., "Enrich". synthetic.id Vector synthetic RNA id, e.g. c("Syn1","Syn2"), default: NULL.

title: Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
text: Enone object

title: Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
text: Description slot: assay SummarizedExperiment::Assays object, contains counts. counts list holding raw/normalized counts sample spike_in. enone_factor list holding normalization factors sample spike_in. enone_metrics data frame normalization methods row metrics columns. enone_score data frame normalization methods row scores columns. enrichment list holding differential analysis results. enrichment_filtered lists holding filtered differential analysis results. parameter list parameters.

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
code: edgeRDE(   counts,   group,   norm.factors = NULL,   adjust.factors = NULL,   design.formula = NULL,   contrast.df = NULL,   coef = NULL,   logfc.cutoff = 1,   p.cutoff = 0.05,   only.pos = TRUE )

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
text: counts un-normalized counts data matrix. group Vector length p mapping columns counts corresponding samples group. norm.factors Vector normalization factors p length. adjust.factors Matrix column indicates adjusting factors estimated RUV. design.formula Formula contrast.df Data frame contrast, extracting results first column vs. second column. coef Integer character vector indicating coefficients linear model tested equal zero. Values must columns column names design. logfc.cutoff Filter genes least X-fold difference (log2-scale) two groups samples, default: 1. p.cutoff Filter genes Y adjusted p-value, default: 0.05. .pos return positive genes filtered results res.sig.ls, default: TRUE.

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
text: List containing differential analysis object, result table filtered result table.

what: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
title: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
text: Normalization assessment one function

title: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
code: enONE(   object,   auto = TRUE,   return.norm = FALSE,   n.neg.control = 1000,   n.pos.eval = 500,   n.neg.eval = 500,   neg.control = NULL,   pos.eval = NULL,   neg.eval = NULL,   scaling.method = c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"),   ruv.norm = TRUE,   ruv.k = 1,   ruv.drop = 0,   eval.pam.k = 2:6,   eval.pc.n = 3 )

title: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
text: object Enone object. auto Whether automatically select negative control, positive evaluation negative evaluation genes, default: TRUE. return.norm Whether return normalized counts object. default, return normalized counts reducing memory costs. n.neg.control Number negative control genes RUV normalization, default: 1000. n.pos.eval Number positive evaluation genes wanted variation assessment, default: 500. n.neg.eval Number negative evaluation genes unwanted variation assessment, default: 500. neg.control Vector negative control genes' id RUV normalization, default: NULL. pos.eval Vector positive evaluation genes' id wanted variation assessment, default: NULL. neg.eval Vector negative evaluation genes' id unwanted variation assessment, default: NULL. scaling.method Vector scaling methods applied data. Available methods : c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"). Select one multiple methods. default scaling methods applied. ruv.norm Whether perform RUV normalization. ruv.k number factors unwanted variation estimated data, default: 1. ruv.drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default: 0. eval.pam.k Integer vector integers indicates number clusters PAM clustering performance evaluation, default: 2:6. eval.pc.n Integer indicates evaluation metrics calculated first nth PCs, default: 3.

title: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
text: Enone object.

what: Remove unwanted variation using control genes — enRUVg

code: enRUVg(object, log = TRUE, k = 1, tolerance = 1e-08, control.idx, drop = 1)

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes — enRUVg
text: object counts matrix. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix, default: TRUE. k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. tolerance Tolerance selection number positive singular values, .e., singular value must larger tolerance considered positive. control.idx ID control genes. drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes — enRUVg
text: list contain matrix unwanted factors (W) corrected counts matrix (normalizedCounts).

what: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
text: object counts matrix. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix, default: TRUE. k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. tolerance Tolerance selection number positive singular values, .e., singular value must larger tolerance considered positive. control.idx ID control genes. sc.idx numeric matrix specifying replicate samples compute count differences used estimate factors unwanted variation (see details). drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
text: list contain matrix unwanted factors (W) corrected counts matrix (normalizedCounts).

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
text: row sc.idx correspond set replicate samples. number columns size largest set replicates; rows smaller sets padded -1 values. example, sets replicate samples (1,2,3),(4,5),(6,7,8), scIdx 1 2 3 4 5 -1 6 7 8
